title: duckdb, webR virt file sys
text:
where to write usa output

fp <- here("data")
if (!dir.exists(fp)) dir.create(fp)
usa_out <- paste0(
  "oil_", c("crude_usa", "oil_refined"), 
  c(".parquet", ".csv")[1]
)

title: duckdb, webR virt file sys
duckdb, webR virt file sys
section: delete old folder if exists, then write parquet
text:
delete old folder if exists, then write parquet

# delete old folder if exists, then write parquet
fp_usa <- here(fp, usa_out)
del_fn(fp_usa[1])
dat$oil_crude %>% 
  filter(ISOcountry == "US") %>%
  group_by(ISOcountry) |> 
  arrow::write_parquet(sink = fp_usa[1])

del_fn(fp_usa[2])
dat$oil_refined %>% 
  filter(country == "USA") %>%
  group_by(direction) |> 
  arrow::write_parquet(sink = fp_usa[2])

title: usethis targets
text:
github_actions

RIX GH workflows

https://github.com/b-rodrigues/rix/tree/master/.github/workflows
https://github.com/JohnGavin/test_nixpkgs/blob/main/.github/workflows/test_pkgs.yml
https://orchid00.github.io/actions_sandbox/index.html#what-are-github-actions ’’‘{r} usethis::use_github_action_check_standard(save_as = “R-CMD-check.yaml”) usethis::use_github_action_check_release(save_as = “R-CMD-check.yaml”) use_github_action()’’’

https://orchid00.github.io/actions_sandbox/index.html#what-are-github-actions
https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/reference/tar_github_actions.html
https://github.com/ThinkR-open/attachment/blob/master/dev/dev_history.R
https://ryo-n7.github.io/2021-09-23-CanPL-GoogleDrive-GithubActions-Tutorial/

Write .github/workflows/targets.yaml workflow file and commit this file to Git

tar_github_actions()

upload the results to the targets-runs branch of your repository.
Subsequent runs add new commits but not necessarily rerun targets

If CI (GH actions) yaml uses devtools::install()

=> Suggests packages not installed

=> devtools::install()(dep = TRUE) in your yaml file ?


{svglite} in {ggplot2}’s suggests, not imports

https://rtask.thinkr.fr/tame-your-namespace-with-a-dash-of-suggests
https://rtask.thinkr.fr/checkhelper-is-on-cran-so-you-dont-have-to-be-afraid-to-run-a-check/
Adding {svglite} to Depends

devtools::check() warns if mandatory dependencies (imports) > 21

=> put as many dependencies as possible in Suggests
Suggests iff
dependencies intended for developers (e.g. {testthat})
vignettes call ggplot2::ggplot (https://adv-r.hadley.nz/)

=> Suggests: ggplots

not necessarily useful to user, including :

packages associated with functions that are rarely used by the user!
packages used only in examples, tests and/or vignettes


if dependency on {svglite} in deptrapr::save_plot() :

imports if : save_plot() is a flagship function of the package it is regularly used (in which case we can add svg to the default formats)
suggest if : save_plot() is a very rarely used function it is only used in the save_plot() example Note that, with this way of doing things, no need to wait until you’ve got 21 dependencies to start sorting, right ?


delete previous roxygen2 line to remove the {svglite} imports

usethis::usepackage(package = "svglite", type = "Suggests")
AND suggests => add if(requireNamespace()) {…} else {…}

cf usethis::usepackage() output


avoid conflicts: Packages not imported

=> not part of the NAMESPACE
=> call as pkg::function() in your code

e.g. ALL Suggests functions used?



{attachment} makes it easier to manage the dependencies

if not going to CRAN move all to Depends usethis::

auto-manages DESCRIPTION <-> NAMESPACE mapping


```{r] # andto write the pipeline using the tar_target() function pkgs_proj <- c( # # proj pkgs from rix::rix( … ) ‘sandwich’, ‘lmtest’, ‘tidyfit’, ‘tibbletime’, ‘roll’, ‘patchwork’, ‘tarchetypes’, ‘fs’, ‘glue’, ‘here’ # from tidyverse, # ‘lubridate’ ) pkgs_proj %>% purrr::map(~ usethis::use_package(., “Imports”) ) use_package(“pacman”, “Imports”) # yes if in code use_package(“purrr”, “Imports”) # yes if in code use_package(“stringr”) # needed in plan_preamble.R # use_package(here() %>% basename(), “Depends”) # exporting funs ?

title: webR in Quarto HTML Documents
text:
Source
install an R-Universe package

=> install its dependencies manually
e.g. add crayon to yaml webr.packages

crayon a dependency of collateral




Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.






Note



If you install an R-Universe package, you currently have to install its dependencies manually. For example, I added crayon, a dependency of collateral, to my frontmatter under webr.packages.








Tip



Try tapping on that textbox and changing the code to bad_mtcars |> summary().








Yes, it can do plots too





This post’s example with {collateral} just has text output, but yes, quarto-webr can do plots too! Here’s a basic example with base R plotting, but you can install ggplot2 and any of your usual extensions through CRAN or R-Universe, of course!

title: webR and dashboard
text:
Sidebar

Richard McElreath’s scientific framework
causal inference & model-based stats
analyze effect of smoking on birth weight

mosaicData::babies dataset
tidyverse and ggdag packages


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


# this chunk runs locally not in webpage
require(tidyverse)
## Loading required package: tidyverse
R.version.string %>% paste(3, .) %>% print()
## [1] "3 R version 4.4.0 (2024-04-24)"
R.version.string %>% paste(4, .) 
## [1] "4 R version 4.4.0 (2024-04-24)"
print(R.version.string) 
## [1] "R version 4.4.0 (2024-04-24)"

title: webR and dashboard
text:
DAG: A directed acyclic graph

Row 1

Column 1

draw a causal diagram

relationship between smoking and birth weight
any potential confounders




Column 2

causal assumptions
structure of data-generating process
identify

confounding variables
sources of bias
potential interventions





Row 3

title: webR and dashboard
section: Golem: A statistical model or estimator
text:
Golem: A statistical model or estimator

approximates the causal model and data
specified using formulas, priors, likelihoods, and algorithms
validated by checking its fit, predictions, and diagnostics

title: webR and dashboard
text:
Owl: analyze the golem

set of procedures and tools
answer the scientific questions

posterior summaries, hypothesis tests, effect sizes, counterfactuals, and sensitivity analyses
simulating data from the statistical model

to check its validity and robustness
